title: 115_hr1262
content: SECTION 1. TAX REPORTING FOR LIFE SETTLEMENT TRANSACTIONS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section requiring returns for certain life insurance contract transactions. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code mandates reporting of specific details for life insurance contract transactions, including the names, addresses, and TINs of involved parties, sale date, issuer information, and payment amounts. Every person required to make a return under this subsection must provide a written statement to each person listed in the return, including the contact information and required return details. For life insurance contracts, the statement does not need to include certain information. Additionally, reporting the seller's basis in life insurance contracts is required. Upon receipt of the required statement or notice of transfer of a life insurance contract to a foreign person, the issuer must submit a return with seller's details, investment in the contract, and policy number. Sellers must provide a written statement to individuals listed in the return. Every person making a payment of reportable death benefits must submit a return with details of the payment, including the name, address, and TIN of the person making the payment and each recipient. The return must include the name, address, and TIN of each recipient, the date and amount of each payment. Additionally, a written statement must be provided to each recipient with the name, address, and phone number of the information contact, along with the required payment details. Definitions for this section include the meaning of 'payment' as cash and consideration transferred in a reportable policy sale, 'reportable policy sale' as defined in section 101(a)(3)(B), 'issuer' as a life insurance company bearing risk, and 'reportable death benefits' as amounts paid due to the death of the insured under a transferred life insurance contract. A statement is required to be furnished under subsection (a)(2), or a notice of a transfer of a life insurance contract to a foreign person has been received. Section 6050X requires returns for certain life insurance contract transactions. Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code to include this new section. Section 6050X requires returns for specific life insurance contract transactions. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code to accommodate this new section, including exemptions from reporting under section 6047. The amendments made by this section apply to reportable policy sales and death benefits paid after December 31, 2017. SEC. 2. CLARIFICATION OF TAX BASIS OF LIFE INSURANCE CONTRACTS. The amendment to section 1016(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 clarifies deductions for taxes, carrying charges, circulation expenditures, and charges under annuity or life insurance contracts. Effective after August 25, 2009. SEC. 3. EXCEPTION TO TRANSFER FOR VALUABLE CONSIDERATION RULES. The amendment to section 101 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces an exception to valuable consideration rules for commercial transfers involving life insurance contracts. This exception applies to reportable policy sales where the acquirer has no substantial family, business, or financial relationship with the policyholder. The amendment to section 101 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces an exception to valuable consideration rules for commercial transfers involving life insurance contracts. This exception applies to reportable policy sales where the acquirer has no substantial family, business, or financial relationship with the insured apart from the acquirer's interest in the life insurance contract. The term 'indirectly' applies to the acquisition of an interest in a partnership, trust, or other entity that holds an interest in the life insurance contract unless the insured is an existing or former employee, officer, director, 5-percent owner, or independent contractor of the acquired entity or its subsidiaries or predecessors. The amendment to section 101 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces an exception to valuable consideration rules for commercial transfers involving life insurance contracts. This exception applies to reportable policy sales where the acquirer has no substantial family, business, or financial relationship with the insured apart from the acquirer's interest in the life insurance contract. The gross value of assets of the acquired entity must not consist of more than 50 percent life insurance contracts, or the parties must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Secretary that the acquisition of the life insurance is not the principal purpose of the acquired entity. The amendment to section 101 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces an exception to valuable consideration rules for commercial transfers involving life insurance contracts. This exception specifies the assets of the acquired entity that are considered in the transaction. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to section 101(a) of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to transfers after December 31, 2017.
